post_text:
The GPISD Education Foundation is the oldest education foundation in Texas. They support GPISD in many ways including:

• Education Grants for teachers and classrooms
• Funding field trips
• Awarding student scholarships
• Attendance awards for schools and students

The Education Foundation is conducting its annual Fund Drive. You can support the Education Foundation and all the great work it does with your donations. Donations can be one-time or set up monthly. Support the GPISD Education Foundation and support GPISD students. #WeAreGPISD

post_text:
Speaking up and asking for help is a sign of strength. Only you have the power to improve your health and well-being, and it starts with one conversation. DialCare is here to listen. Middle and high school students can talk to mental health professionals through the DialCare virtual counseling program. Sessions are available in both English and Spanish during after school hours. Visit gpisd.org/DialCare

*This is a free service for GPISD students in Texas. This is not insurance.

post_text: GPISD has updated our Fall Meal Plan. All children under 18 years of age are eligible. All in-person learners can now receive daily cafeteria meals at no cost, while virtual learners can pick up free curbside meals Monday through Friday from 10:30 am to 12:30 pm at five campus locations. Children younger than school age and any non-GPISD students who live in Grand Prairie can also receive free curbside meals. Check the website for locations and details.

post_text:
Grand Prairie ISD is committed to ensuring our classrooms, buses, offices and common areas are clean and disinfected for our students and staff. Our custodial staff and administration have worked diligently the past few months to ensure that we are using the most effective sanitation practices and products.

Our staff uses a hospital-grade germicidal detergent that is safe for students while effectively killing a broad spectrum of bacteria, viruses, and funguses. We invite you to watch the video for information about our cleaning protocols.

For more information visit www.gpisd.org/SafetyPlan

post_text:
This is Virtual Learning.
Dickinson Elementary Gifted and Talented students are developing their critical thinking skills by analyzing real court cases from Colin Seale's Think Law curriculum. Mr. Seale is an educator and former lawyer, who has shared his standards-based innovative program and the concept of “Thinking like a Lawyer” with the GPISD staff during professional development sessions for the last few years. These GT students are engaging in deep conversations, analyzing the cases from multiple perspectives, and examining evidence to justify their own conclusions. These students are learning life-long skills by developing the habits and mindsets needed to apply critical thinking consistently. #WeAreGPISD

post_text: Do you have questions about the movies your kids watch? The apps? The books they read? Common Sense Media is an independent, non-profit, research based resource that empowers parents to be pro-active in monitoring the content their child consumes. From video games to streaming shows, Common Sense Media can give you information like amount of violence, drug use, and language used. You decide how appropriate the media is for your child. Visit commonsensemedia.org to be an informed parent. #BeKindOnline #BeKindGPISD

post_text:
MYTH: Suicide is silent.
REALITY: Suicide is preventable. Youth who are contemplating suicide typically give warning signs of their distress. Most important is to never take these warning signs lightly or promise to keep them secret.

GPISD counselors and social workers are ready to listen. Visit gpisd.org/virtualcounseling or call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-TALK (8255). #BeTheLight

post_text:
Grand Prairie ISD is pleased to announce that we will be named a TAEA Texas Art Education Association District of Distinction. Over 1,000 districts were eligible to apply for this TAEA Visual Arts Award and just forty-two districts will receive this outstanding honor this year. The TAEA Administration and Supervision Division recognizes districts with outstanding leadership in promoting the arts in their district and community.

Congratulations to our wonderful Fine Arts administration and teachers. #WeAreGPISD #BeTheLight

post_text:
Grand Prairie ISD provee transporte de autobús para miles de estudiantes elegibles cada día, y continuaremos a proveer autobuses limpios y seguros para nuestros estudiantes. El video mencionado abajo provee información sobre los procedimientos de limpieza aumentados que implementaremos para los autobuses.

El transporte por autobús comienza el lunes 14 de septiembre para estudiantes elegibles que regresarán a clases en persona de prekínder a 2do grado y estudiantes de programación de Educación Especial identificada como clases autónomas cuyos padres eligieron clases en persona.

El transporte por autobús comienza el lunes 21 de septiembre para estudiantes elegibles que regresarán a clases en persona de los grados de 3 al 12 cuyos padres eligieron clases en persona.

Pueden consultar el sitio web de GPISD para revisar elegibilidad y encontrar información sobre las rutas de autobús.

post_text:
Grand Prairie ISD provides transportation for thousands of eligible students each day and will continue to provide clean, safe buses for our students. Please watch the video below for enhanced bus safety and cleaning procedures.

Bus transportation begins on Monday, September 14 for eligible students returning to in-person instruction for Pre-K through 2nd grade and identified self-contained special education programming students whose parents chose in-person learning.

Bus transportation begins on Monday, September 21 for eligible students returning to in-person instruction for students in grades 3 through 12 whose parents chose in-person learning.

post_text:
For the first time since March, GPISD will welcome back Pre-K-2nd grade and identified self-contained special education programming students who chose in-person learning on Mon. Sept. 14, 2020. GPISD staff members have been working for months to prepare our schools so students may return safely to in-person learning.

The two-step plan to return to in-person learning is:

Pre-K-2nd grade and identified self-contained special education programming students:

The first day for in-person learning for all of our Pre-K, kindergarten, 1st grade, 2nd grade and identified self-contained special education programming students whose parents chose in-person learning is Monday, September 14, 2020.

3rd through 12th grade students:

The first day for in-person learning for all of our 3rd-12th graders whose parents chose in-person learning is Mon., Sept. 21, 2020.

Please watch the video below to see the safety protocols you can expect on a typical school day as we return to in-person learning next week.

We are so excited to see you!

post_text:
Grand Prairie ISD uses STOPit, an online and app-based reporting system, for students and parents to anonymously report concerns about school violence, bullying, and self-injury to school administrators. The app is pre-loaded onto all 6-12 iPads and can be found in Self-Service for elementary students.

If you see something...say something. #STOPit #BeKindGPISD

post_text: Congratulations Ms Henry! #WeAreGPISD
shared_text:
South Grand Prairie High School
September 7 at 8:00 PM ·

South Grand Prairie Teacher and marathon runner, Shelby Henry, qualified for the 2020 Boston Marathon and had her plane ticket when the event got rescheduled and then canceled due to the coronavirus pandemic. Qualifying runners were given the option to run the marathon "virtually" and report their times.

Mrs. Henry virtually ran the Boston Marathon today September 7th. SGP is so proud of you and all your hard work

Shelby is the South Grand Prairie's Education and Training Courses teacher; the CTE Department Chair; Advisor for NHS and the Texas Association of Future

Educators (TAFE). She is also the president-elect of the Texas Gamma Xi Chapter of Alpha Delta Kappa, an International Honorary Organization of Women Educators.

MYTH: Talking about suicide plants the idea in a student's head.
REALITY: Not talking about it can actually increase the intensity of thoughts and feelings.

GPISD counselors and social workers are ready to listen. Visit gpisd.org/virtualcounseling or call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-800-273-TALK (8255). #BeTheLight

post_text:
When In-Person Instruction resumes, all students will be required to wear a mask. Practice wearing a mask correctly so it offers the most protection for you and others.

• Wear a mask in public when you are around people you don't live with.
• Don't put the face covering around your neck or up on your forehead.
• Don't touch the face covering.
• If you touch your mask, wash your hands or use hand sanitizer.

#WearAMask #BeKindGPISD

It’s time to empower our students with the knowledge and encourage dialogue with the help from the virtual counseling program through DialCare. Middle and high school students now have access to safe, secure, and private means of seeking help from licensed mental health professionals via phone or video chat for free during after school hours. Visit www.gpisd.org/DialCare for more information.

*This is a free service for GPISD students in Texas. This is not insurance.

post_text:
GPISD counselors strive to be responsive to the needs of our students and families. Yanira asks how to keep her students motivated during online learning.
• Encourage accountability by making a checklist of things to accomplish and check them off

• Establish a route that includes lunch and physical activity breaks

• Help students manage stress by chunking large assignments into smaller portions and allowing them to listen to music while working independently.

If you have questions for GPISD counselors or social workers, visit www.gpisd.org/virtualcounseling for help. #BeKindOnline #BeKindGPISD

post_text: Mae Talley, IMA at Ellen Ochoa STEM Academy at Ben Milam Elementary, has been selected as a LEGO Education Master Educator to help celebrate hands-on & STEAM learning. Ms. Talley sponsors the FIRST LEGO League Robotics Club as well as collaborates with other teachers around the country through the LEGO Education Community Team. The nation-wide team shares ideas and lessons for teachers to use in their classrooms. Ms. Talley was chosen as a Master Educator for the second year in a row. #WeAreGPISD

post_text:
On August 27, the GPISD Board of Trustees voted to set the tax rate for 2020-2021 at $1.5097 per $100 of valuation. This is a decrease of nearly $0.03 from last year ($0.02865). The overall tax rate is made up of two parts:

• $1.0547 for the purpose of maintenance and operations
• $0.4550 for the purpose of payment of principal and interest on debts

Including this year’s tax rate decrease, the GPISD Board of Trustees has lowered the tax rate by just over eight and a half cents over a two-year period. #WeAreGPISD

GPISD.ORG

• $0.4550 for the purpose of payment of principal and interest on debts

Including this year’s tax rate decrease, the GPISD Board of Trustees has lowered the tax rate by just over eight and a half cents over a two-year period. #WeAreGPISD

It’s important for teens to know that speaking up and asking for help is a sign of strength. If you are wondering where to look for help, turn to DialCare. Through DialCare’s virtual counseling program, middle and high school students can seek help by scheduling a private counseling session* with a licensed mental health professional via phone or video chat. No one should have to do it alone. DialCare is here to help. Visit gpisd.org/VirtualLearning

*This is a free service for GPISD students in Texas. This is not insurance.

post_text:
This is Virtual Learning.
In this high school U.S. history lesson, students will do a historical thinking investigation to actually think like a historian. The lesson includes a video background section, analyzing an image, reading primary source documents, and responding to investigation questions. Students have the option to respond in written or video form while providing evidence for their conclusions.

Teachers work to provide high-level lessons in a virtual setting. #WeAreGPISD

post_text:
This is Virtual Learning:
These first graders worked in small groups to read, represent, solve, and explain story problems using a virtual problem-solving mat and sticky notes. GPISD’s students use the process TEKS each day during this 15-minute routine. Problem-solving begins in Pre-K and continues to graduation and beyond. #WeAreGPISD

post_text:
For Families with students in GPISD....
The GPISD Social Work Hub is partnering with Gateway Church to do a Drive-Thru Food Pantry. The event will be held on Saturday, September 12, 2020 from 11 am to 1 pm. Families with a student in GPISD must be registered to participate. Call 972.522.7070 to register. The deadline to register is Sept. 5, 2020.

Parents will be required to remain in their vehicles and must wear masks at check-in. #BeTheLight

Wear a mask and wear it properly to help stop the spread of COVID-19.
• Wash your hands before putting on your face covering.
• Put it over your nose and mouth and secure it under your chin.
• Try to fit it snuggly against the sides of your face.
• Make sure you can breathe easily.

We are all in this together. #BeKindGPISD

post_text:
Virtual Learning can be stressful. When it comes to our student’s health and well-being, early identification and providing appropriate services for students and their families can make a difference. That’s where the virtual counseling program through DialCare comes in. Middle and high school students can connect with mental health professionals who can work with conditions such as depression, stress, anxiety, relationships, grief, eating disorders, addiction and more.* Sessions are available in both English and Spanish during after school hours. For more information, visit gpisd.org/DialCare.

All students can visit gpisd.org/VirtualCounseling to reach out to a GPISD counselor.

*This is a free service for GPISD students in Texas. This is not insurance.

All GPISD parents have received an email last week announcing that GPISD Child Nutrition is resuming Pick Up Meal Service on Monday, August 17 at eleven locations. Meals are either free, reduced priced, or paid based on individual student’s eligibility. That eligibility is determined by filling out the free and reduced-price meal application. That application is found in Skyward or you can link to it directly at gpisd.org/MealApplication.

More information including prices, map to schools, and how to check your eligibility can be found at www.gpisd.org/fallmealpickup.

post_text:
Virtual Attendance Information
A new way of school means a new way of taking attendance. As teachers account for the students through remote attendance, the student is marked Remote Asynchronous - Present. Parents will see a “V” in Family Access Attendance for “Virtually Present.” This is different from the past when you only saw an attendance mark if the student was absent. Parents will now see an attendance mark of “V” when the student is Virtually Present. #WeAreGPISD
text:

post_text:
When life brings us unexpected and overwhelming challenges, a wide range of emotions follow. It can be a lot to deal with, but we want our students to know they are not alone. DialCare is here to help and here to listen. Parents, through a virtual counseling program, your middle or high school student can connect with a licensed mental health professional via phone or video chat for free. Sessions are available in both English and Spanish, during after school hours. Visit gpisd.org/DialCare to learn more.

*This is a free service for GPISD students in Texas. This is not insurance.

post_text:
Welcome back, GPISD students and families, to the 2020-2021 school year! Our first day of virtual learning begins tomorrow--Monday, August 17, 2020. Grand Prairie ISD is committed to providing a successful online experience for all students. We are attaching a resource to help students and parents get started with online learning on day one of virtual school.

Though we are beginning virtually, we still want to share the excitement of a new school year with you. Please use #GPISDFirstDay2020 to share your pictures.

For information and help connect to GPISD Technology at gpisd.org/techdayone
Or in Spanish at gpisd.org/tecnologia1erdia

post_text:
August 9 is the United Nations International Day of the World’s Indigenous People. There are over 476 million indigenous peoples living in 90 countries across the world, accounting for 6.2% of the global population.
Indigenous peoples are the holders of unique cultures, traditions, and
knowledge systems and have a special relationship with their lands and hold diverse concepts of development based on their own worldviews and priorities. For more information visit https://www.un.org/en/observances/indigenous-day

As we return to school virtually on August 17 and eventually in-person, GPISD will continue to provide healthful meals to our students. Even though our district is beginning the year fully virtual, we still have opportunities for your child(ren) to receive healthful meals. To see if your child is eligible for free meals or reduced meal prices, please go to the link below and fill out the free and reduced meal application. Applications are available in English and Spanish at gpisd.org.MealApplication.

You can request a paper application either from your campus or from the GPISD Food Services Office at 2341 S. Belt Line Road, Grand Prairie, TX 7505. Call the Food Services office at 972-343-4410 if you have additional questions. #WeAreGPISD

post_text: August is Be Kind: Make New Friends Month. Making friends when we are not in school can be hard. One of the first friends GPISD families can make is their school counselor and/or social worker. They are available to help you with your academic and emotional needs. Our secondary students can access DialCare for counseling online or on the phone, Elementary students can reach out to their counselors by email or phone. GPISD cares about the mental health of our families as well as our student's academic successes. #BeKindGPISD #JointheMovement

post_text:
A recent opinion from Attorney General Ken Paxton indicates that a local health authority is not permitted to issue sweeping school-closure orders. Based on this statement, the Texas Education Agency has revised its guidelines.

At this time, GPISD will continue with the plan that we previously shared with our families. All Grand Prairie ISD students will start school on Monday, August 17, 2020. All instruction will be online until Sept. 8, 2020.

Beginning Tuesday, September 8, students whose families chose in-person learning will report to their schools in person, following all safety precautions in place at that time. Students whose families chose online learning will continue with that model and will remain at home.

Registration and enrollment for new and returning students is taking place now. To register a student and choose an instructional model for him or her, simply follow this link: https://www.gpisd.org/registration

We appreciate your flexibility as we work together to navigate these challenging times. Thank you for your support as we start the 2020-2021 school year.

Beginning Tuesday, September 8, students whose families chose in-person learning will report to their schools in person, following all safety precautions in place at that time. Students whose families chose online learning will continue with that model and will remain at home.

Registration and enrollment for new and returning students is taking place now. To register a student and choose an instructional model for him or her, simply follow this link: https://www.gpisd.org/registration

We appreciate your flexibility as we work together to navigate these challenging times. Thank you for your support as we start the 2020-2021 school year.

It’s OK not to be OK. Don’t see it as a personal failure, but a chance for you to put yourself and your health first! That’s where DialCare’s virtual counseling program comes in. Middle and high school students can connect with mental health professionals who can assist with conditions such as depression, stress, anxiety, relationships, grief, eating disorders, addiction and more. Visit gpisd.org/DialCare

*This is a free service for GPISD students in Texas. This is not insurance.

post_text:
P-EBT Update
The deadline to apply for P-EBT food benefits has been extended to August 21. If your child received free or reduced-price school meals through the National School Lunch Program during the 2019-2020 school year, your family may be eligible for this one-time food benefit. Visit hhs.texas.gov/pebt to learn more about P-EBT. For questions regarding eligibility or if you need help applying, contact the P-EBT Call Center at 833-613-6220. The public charge rule does not apply to P-EBT benefits.

post_text:
Grand Prairie ISD is pleased to announce that Amanda Schmitter has been named Principal of Sam Rayburn Elementary STEAM Academy.

She has an undergraduate degree from Texas Christian University and her master’s degree from The University of North Texas. She has served in GPISD for 15 years as a classroom teacher and campus administrator. She began her career as a teacher at Florence Hill Elementary and then at Mike Moseley Elementary. Her leadership journey has taken her to Austin Elementary, Mike Moseley Elementary, Marshall Leadership Academy, Powell Elementary, and Garner Fine Arts Academy.

“I have been a part of so many wonderful programs in our district aimed at the success of our students,” Amanda said. “I have also had the pleasure of working with so many dynamic leaders in GPISD and am so thankful for them.” #WeAreGPISD

post_text:
Grand Prairie ISD is pleased to announce that Mesias Trejo has been named the Principal of Hobbs Williams Elementary. Mr. Trejo is entering his 13th year of service in Texas Public Schools. He has served as a bilingual classroom teacher, an instructional coach, and an assistant principal. He obtained a Bachelor of Arts degree in Psychology from the University of North Texas and a Master of Adult Education degree from Jones International University. Mr. Trejo believes that every child should be given the opportunity to be successful with a great public education. It is important to him to create a culture that promotes the ongoing improvement of learning and teaching for students and staff.

Congratulations to Mr. Trejo and Hobbs Williams Elementary. #WeAreGPISD

post_text:
Grand Prairie ISD is pleased to announce that Ami Potts will take the helm as the new Principal at Ronald Reagan Middle. Mrs. Potts is entering her 14th year of service in Texas public schools. She served as an elementary teacher and interventionist for seven years before moving into administration. She obtained a Bachelor of Science in Education from Texas Wesleyan and a Masters of Education Administration from Lamar University. Her goal is for all students to discover a love for learning, attain success, be challenged to reach their greatest potential, and leave knowing that they can achieve anything.

Congratulations to Mrs. Potts and Reagan Middle School. #WeAreGPISD
text:
Grand Prairie ISD is pleased to announce that Ami Potts will take the helm as the new Principal at Ronald Reagan Middle. Mrs. Potts is entering her 14th year of service in Texas public schools. She served as an elementary teacher and interventionist for seven years before moving into administration. She obtained a Bachelor of Science in Education from Texas Wesleyan and a Masters of Education Administration from Lamar University. Her goal is for all students to discover a love for learning, attain success, be challenged to reach their greatest potential, and leave knowing that they can achieve anything.

Congratulations to Mrs. Potts and Reagan Middle School. #WeAreGPISD

post_text:
How will GPISD take attendance when students are working from home and receiving Virtual Online Instruction?

Students earn daily attendance through one or more daily engagement measures.

* Daily progress in the assignments included in the online platform (Google Classroom for Elementary and Canvas for Secondary)
* Daily progress via teacher-student interactions or
* Completion/Turn-in of assignments from student to teacher (potentially via email, on-line, or through mail)

For more detailed information visit gpisd.org/RoadmapToReopening

post_text: The deadline to apply for P-EBT food benefits has been extended to July 31. Did your child receive free or reduced-price school meals through the National School Lunch Program during the 2019-2020 school year? If so, your family may be eligible for this one-time food benefit. Visit hhs.texas.gov/pebt to learn more about P-EBT. For questions regarding eligibility or if you need help applying, contact the P-EBT Call Center at 833-613-6220. The public charge rule does not apply to P-EBT benefits.

post_text:
What is the difference in Synchronous and Asynchronous Instruction?
You will see both of these terms used for Virtual Online Instruction.

Synchronous instruction means two-way, real-time, live instruction between teachers and students through a digital device. This means the teacher and student are both on screen at the same time interacting.

Asynchronous instruction may include various forms of digital and online learning, such as direct virtual instruction, prerecorded video lessons or game-based learning tasks that students complete on their own, pre-assigned worksheets, and formative assessments. The teacher and student are not interacting in real-time.

Both types of instruction will be delivered by highly qualified GPISD staff.

More detailed information is available at gpisd.org/RoadmapToReopening

Speaking up and asking for help is a sign of strength. Only you have the power to improve your health and well-being, and it starts with one conversation. DialCare is here to listen. Middle and high school students, you can talk to mental health professionals through the DialCare virtual counseling program.* Sessions are available in both English and Spanish during after school hours. Visit gpisd.org/DialCare

*This is a free service for GPISD students in Texas. This is not insurance.

post_text:
Garner Fine Arts Academy's art teacher and counselor teamed up to do a project, Art for Change, with some of their students. Art for Change was designed to give students a safe place to share their concerns, ask questions, and have a creative outlet to express themselves regarding the social injustice in society. The students wanted to use their original artwork to make an impact on their community. The Art for Change group is collecting for a donation to Grand Prairie United Charities.
There are two ways to help!

We are selling prints for a minimum donation of $10. Click here to order a print:
https://forms.gle/yvDdYaG8CokawMGA6

If you would like to contribute without ordering a print click here: https://www.paypal.com/pools/c/8qAoxTXeX6

Here is a link for parents to other resources on talking to your kids about race: https://www.pbs.org/parents/talking-about-racism

We are so proud of these students for using their artistic talents to promote change in our community. #WeAreGPISD

post_text: Congratulations to Dubiski Career High School and Dr. Holly Mohler.
shared_text:
Dubiski Career High School
July 14 at 1:16 PM ·

Join us in welcoming our new Principal of Dubiski Career High School, Dr. Holly Mohler!

Dr. Mohler comes to Dubiski with experience as a Classroom Teacher, Campus and District Strategist, Instructional Dean at SGPHS, and the founding Principal of School for the Highly Gifted in GPISD. She is beginning her 17th year in education with 14 of those years in Grand Prairie.

She earned her bachelor’s degree from Baylor University, a master’s degree from the University of Texas at Arlington, and her doctoral degree from Texas A&M University. She finds joy in partnering with staff and families to find creative and unique opportunities for all students to succeed and grow.

Welcome to Dubiski, Dr. Mohler!

post_text: To the amazing Class of 2020...while you have graduated, GPISD is still providing support virtually with the Beat the Heat program to help avoid summer melt. College advisors and counselors will be available this summer to help recent graduates transition successfully to college, career, or military. You will be able to set up appointments with an advisor, and they will able to assist with any questions or concerns you have. There will also be webinar series throughout the summer hosted by different universities to discuss college updates. GPISD is committed to supporting the Class of 2020 transition successfully to their future plans. Please visit gpisd.org/BeatTheHeat for resources. #WeAreGPISD

post_text:
Uncertain times and disruptions in their normal routine can cause anxiety and worry in children and teens. Help your child manage their stress in these ways:
• Welcome their questions.
• Don’t avoid questions you can’t answer.
• Set the tone.
• Be developmentally appropriate.
• Take your cues from your child.
• Deal with your own anxiety.
• Be reassuring.
• Focus on what you’re doing to stay safe.
• Keep talking.

Resources: childmind.org, commonsense.org. #BeKindGPISD

You can email your questions to CustomerService@gpisd.org.

EDIT: GPISD is compiling your questions and working on a FAQ that will be available on the website. Thank you for being patient as we work toward the best and safest solutions for our families and staff. Please email your questions to CustomerService@gpisd.org.

GPISD staff is busy planning for a safe return to school on August 17, 2020. We are creating plans that will include comprehensive health and safety protocols for all staff and students. In addition, we have worked to create instructional options that meet the needs of our families. These plans include both an in-school and an online virtual-school option called “asynchronous learning.”

Beginning July 14, 2020, families will be able to complete online registration for the 2020-2021 school year. For more information visit gpisd.org/roadmaptoreopening. #WeAreGPISD #GPISDstillLeading

In the course, students learn about the history and cultural contributions of Mexican Americans. Students explore history and culture from an interdisciplinary perspective. The curriculum utilizes the ABC-CLIO The Latino American Experience: The American Mosaic. Students began registering for the course for the coming school year in the spring. New student registration will begin July. #WeAreGPISD #GPISDstillLeading

post_text:
Darkness cannot drive out darkness; only light can do that. Hate cannot drive out hate; only love can do that. - Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr

It can be hard to have conversations about racial issues. These guidelines can help you talk about race and social injustice with your children.
1. Embrace your child’s difference. Make it clear how much you care about them, how their differences are a gift, not a liability, and how not everyone will view it as a positive.
2. Correct misperceptions the world has about people who are diverse. We certainly know the adult world is filled with misinformation after a racist incident makes news. Kids hear that too. Help them better understand that no one is less human than another.
3. Monitor your child’s emotions before, during, and after the conversation. Say, “this is an ongoing conversation.” You’re going to keep talking about these issues and they should too. When another incident makes headlines, follow up.
4. Listen. Don’t assume you are the only one with wisdom to bring to the conversation. Children teach us too. #BeKindGPISD
text:
Darkness cannot drive out darkness; only light can do that. Hate cannot drive out hate; only love can do that. - Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr

It can be hard to have conversations about racial issues. These guidelines can help you talk about race and social injustice with your children.
1. Embrace your child’s difference. Make it clear how much you care about them, how their differences are a gift, not a liability, and how not everyone will view it as a positive.
2. Correct misperceptions the world has about people who are diverse. We certainly know the adult world is filled with misinformation after a racist incident makes news. Kids hear that too. Help them better understand that no one is less human than another.
3. Monitor your child’s emotions before, during, and after the conversation. Say, “this is an ongoing conversation.” You’re going to keep talking about these issues and they should too. When another incident makes headlines, follow up.
4. Listen. Don’t assume you are the only one with wisdom to bring to the conversation. Children teach us too. #BeKindGPISD

When it comes to our student’s health and well-being, early identification and providing appropriate services for students and their families can make a difference! That’s where the virtual counseling program through DialCare comes in. Middle and high school students can connect with mental health professionals who can work with conditions such as depression, stress, anxiety, relationships, grief, eating disorders, addiction and more.* Sessions are available in both English and Spanish during after school hours. For more information, click here: gpisd.org/DialCare
*This is a free service for GPISD students in Texas. This is not insurance.

post_text:
At the June 22 called meeting of the GPISD Board of Trustees, the Board made a bold statement to address issues of racial equity in our community. By a unanimous vote, the Board adopted a sweeping resolution that commits the Trustees and the Superintendent of Schools to taking action. The resolution calls for equity and cultural bias training as well as the formation of a Racial Equity Committee comprised of Board-appointed community members and at least two Board members.

The resolution states the Board stands in solidarity with its students and community to declare that the lives of black students and black people matter. It goes on to clarify that this declaration “does not
negate the commitment to serve all students but rather reaffirms the Board’s commitment to addressing the disparities and inequity of different student groups.”

The full text of the resolution may be found at gpisd.org/EquityResolution
#WeAreGPISD #GPISDstillLeading

Grand Prairie ISD teachers are creative and ambitious. Felica Horne, a 3rd-grade teacher at Sallye Moore College and Career Preparatory Academy is now a published author. Ms. Horne was looking for a resource for teaching alliteration and could not find exactly what she was looking for, so she wrote her own book to better convey the concepts to her students. Ms. Horne wrote an alliteration ABC book that is can be found on Amazon, Barnes & Noble, and at http://felicafarris.com.

Congratulations to Ms. Horne for writing great curriculum resources for everyone. #GPISDstillLeading #WewAreGPISD

post_text:
EDITED
Grand Prairie ISD has included an African American Studies course in the academic catalog for the 20-21 school year for students in grades 9-12. African American Studies is a conceptually driven course that introduces students to the exploration of the rich and diverse history and culture of African Americans. The goal of this course is to broaden the knowledge and understanding of students interested in learning about history, citizenship, culture, economics, science, technology, geography, and the political realities of African Americans. Students began to sign up for this new course in the spring of 2020 for the upcoming school year. New student registration will begin in early July. #WeAreGPISD

EDIT: Several have asked about the curriculum that will be used. GPISD has adopted The African-American Experience: The American Mosiac (Academic) by ABC-CLIO Solutions. It has been vetted and overseen by Dr. Spencer R. Crew of the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture.

post_text: Grand Prairie ISD is planning the Roadmap to Reopening our schools for the 2020-21 school year. We thank the almost 7000 people who took the Reopening Survey. The results of the survey are important to the district in making decisions as we move forward with plans for the fall. We are looking forward to reopening our school district and can’t wait for August 17, 2020, which is the first day of school whether in person or virtually. On-Line Registration for the new school year will begin in early July. Thank you for your patience and continue to watch our website and social media for information as decisions are finalized. #WeAreGPISD

post_text:
Meet new Grand Prairie ISD School Board Member, Bryan Parra. Mr. Parra was sworn in on Thursday, June 11, 2020 by Dallas County Commissioner, Dr. Elba Garcia.

Mr. Parra is a 2009 graduate of South Grand Prairie High School. He earned his undergraduate from Texas A & M in Race, Gender, & Ethnicity and his Masters from Dallas Baptist University in Educational Leadership. Mr. Parra currently serves as an Assistant Principal in Dallas ISD.

Mr. Parra states that he will focus on engaging the community to hear their concerns and their input on how we can make Grand Prairie Independent School District the best in the state. He is an advocate for public education where student safety, transparency, and building an environment that is welcoming to all students will be priorities.

Mr. Parra states, “By investing in the community, we can make it a better place for all of us to live.”

For more information about the GPISD Board of Trustees please visit gpisd.org/SchoolBoard. #WeAreGPISD

The GPISD Board of Trustees approved a 1-to-1 iPad initiative for K-2nd grade at their monthly meeting last week. The district will purchase 5,650 devices and cases. The bundle will include no service fee for a repair or replacement for students up to two incidents per device per year.

This purchase expands the district's 1:1 initiative to all K-12 students assuring everyone will get the same opportunity for “at-home learning” and in-class collaboration and engagement. #WeAreGPISD

Self-care isn’t selfish. In order to practice self-care, you need to make purposeful choices in your life that make your health and well-being a priority. DialCare is here to let you know you do not have to fight your battle alone. Through DialCare’s virtual counseling program, middle and high school students now have access to safe, secure and private counseling sessions* with mental health professionals via phone or video. Click here to learn more: gpisd.org/DialCare
*This is a free service for GPISD students in Texas. This is not insurance.

post_text: Congratulations to the Class of 2020. While you have graduated, GPISD is still supporting you with the Beat the Heat program to help you avoid the Summer Melt this summer, college advisors and counselors will be available to help recent graduates transition successfully to college, career, or military. There will also be webinar series throughout the summer, topics include financial aid, GPISD alumni panel, coping with stress, college transition meetings, and more. GPISD is committed to supporting the Class of 2020 transition successfully to their future plans. Please visit gpisd.org/BeatTheHeat for resources. #WeAreGPISD

post_text: Raul Medina, Jr is graduating today from Crosswinds Accelerated High School. Raul, 40 yrs old, did not have the opportunity to graduate from high school. His wife and children registered him for Crosswinds and didn't tell him until the day of orientation. Raul's son told him, “Dad, I have faith in you, you got this!” Raul will graduate today at Globe Life Field with his high school diploma proving it's never too late when you have the support of your family. #GPISDGraduates #WeAreGPISD

post_text:
Multi-District Virtual Job Fair
June 10, 2020
1:00pm-4:00pm

Are you ready to shape the future of Texas? Join us at the Teaching Texans Virtual Career Event on June 10 to meet virtually with 13 public school districts from around Texas and explore hundreds of teaching positions across all grades and subject areas including arts, athletics, and special education.

Grand Prairie ISD is committed to growing strong, inspiring leaders at all levels through a fiveyear partnership with The Holdsworth Center. We think you’ll find that Holdsworth partner districts put a strong focus on creating positive learning environments where teachers and students feel motivated to learn and supported to do their best work.
Register now at TeachingTexans.org

post_text:
If you are planning to attend a GPISD Graduation, please be aware of the House Rules for Globe Life Park.

TAILGATING IS NOT PERMITTED. Congregating before and after each ceremony is prohibited.
HEELS ARE NOT PERMITTED. Wedges and espadrilles are allowed. We are excited to hold graduation at the brand new Globe Life Field, and we want to be respectful of the beautiful new facility and its amenities, including the turf.
NO BAGS will be allowed in the venue, unless it is a medical bag or diaper bag.
CONCESSION STANDS WILL NOT BE OPEN.
Guests may bring in one sealed bottle of water. GPISD will provide one sealed bottle of water for each graduate once they arrive at the graduate staging area.
NO SIGNS, AIR HORNS, FLOWERS, OR BALLOONS will be allowed into Globe Life Field.

To see more Graduation information visit gpisd.org/Graduation

post_text:
It’s OK not to be OK. Don’t see it as a personal failure, but a chance for you to put yourself and your health first! That’s where DialCare’s virtual counseling program comes in. Middle and high school students can connect with mental health professionals who can assist with conditions such as depression, stress, anxiety, relationships, grief, eating disorders, addiction and more. For more information, click here: gpisd.org/DialCare
*This is a free service for GPISD students in Texas. This is not insurance.

🔹️Qualify for free/reduced-price meals in the 2019-20 school year;

post_text:
The Class of 2020 at Young Women's Leadership Academy at Arnold had a big surprise today! The Dallas Mavericks and Chime, a mobile banking company, gifted each of the seniors with a custom gift basket, a new Dell laptop, and $200 cash. YWLA and 2 other all-girl public schools in north Texas who are also members of the Young Women's Preparatory Network were chosen to receive the gifts. Thank you Mavericks and Chime for a wonderful gift for some very deserving ladies. More pictures can be found on the GPISD Flickr. https://www.flickr.com/photos/grandprairieisd/albums
#WeAreGPISD #GPISDGraduates

#MentalHealthMay
It is healthy to talk about emotions! Ask your friends and family members, “how are you?” and listen to their responses. This shows you care and helps support those who are struggling with life’s challenges or their mental health. Not to mention, talking about mental health also improves other areas of one’s life. #WeAreGPISD

post_text:
Speaking up and asking for help is a sign of strength. Only you have the power to improve your health and well-being, and it starts with one conversation. DialCare is here to listen. Middle and high school students, you can talk to mental health professionals through the DialCare virtual counseling program.* Sessions are available in both English and Spanish during after school hours. Click here to learn more: gpisd.org/DialCare
*This is a free service for GPISD students in Texas. This is not insurance.

post_text: Congratulations Troy, representing GPISD.
shared_text:
Dubiski Career High School
May 22 at 11:29 PM ·

Congratulations to Troy Broussard for being elected as a SkillsUSA Texas State Officer! Troy went through months of local training and a 3-week process including a SkillsUSA knowledge test, virtual interview, campaign speech, and peer voting.

Troy will be one of seven presiding over 23,000+ SkillsUSA Texas State Members. Way to go, Troy!

post_text:
It’s OK not to be OK. Don’t see it as a personal failure, but a chance for you to put yourself and your health first! That’s where DialCare’s virtual counseling program comes in. Middle and high school students can connect with mental health professionals who can assist with conditions such as depression, stress, anxiety, relationships, grief, eating disorders, addiction and more.* For more information, click here: gpisd.org/DialCare
*This is a free service for GPISD students in Texas. This is not insurance.

post_text: Shout out to Joanna Vidales, second-grade teacher at Bowie Fine Arts Academy. Ms. Vidales drove to Waxahachie to deliver a special sign to Andrew. His mom writes, "Andrew was very happy to see her! We are very grateful for everything she taught our son. Ms. Vidales continues to support and encourage Andrew through this epidemic virus as she did daily when he was in her classroom. Andrew never stopped learning because of this virus. She is a wonderful teacher who goes out of her way to support the education of many children. My son is very lucky and blessed to be part of her classroom." #WeAreGPISD #GPISDstillLeading

post_text:
When it comes to our student’s health and well-being, early identification and providing appropriate services for students and their families can make a difference! That’s where the virtual counseling program through DialCare comes in. Middle and high school students can connect with mental health professionals who can work with conditions such as depression, stress, anxiety, relationships, grief, eating disorders, addiction and more.* Sessions are available in both English and Spanish during after school hours. For more information, click here: gpisd.org/dialcare
*This is a free service for GPISD students in Texas. This is not insurance.

post_text:
Self-care isn’t selfish. In order to practice self-care, you need to make purposeful choices in your life that make your health and well-being a priority. DialCare is here to let you know you do not have to fight your battle alone. Through DialCare’s virtual counseling program, middle and high school students now have access to safe, secure and private counseling sessions* with mental health professionals via phone or video. Click here to learn more: gpisd.org/dialcare
*This is a free service for GPISD students in Texas. This is not insurance.

post_text: GPISD knows you have many questions about the upcoming Graduation Ceremonies. Our high school principals are doing a final walkthrough with Globe Life Field officials on Monday. Expect an email from your principal on Tuesday with details about parking, tickets, etc. We know this is an exciting and disappointing time for your families with not having our "normal" graduation activities. We want to make your graduation as history-making as your class has been. #WeAreGPISD #GPISDGraduates

When life brings us unexpected and overwhelming challenges, a wide range of emotions follow. It can be a lot to deal with, but we want our students to know they are not alone. DialCare is here to help and here to listen! Parents, through a virtual counseling program, your middle or high school student can connect with a licensed mental health professional via phone or video chat for free!* Sessions are available in both English and Spanish, during after school hours. Click here to learn more: gpisd.org/dialcare #WeAreGPISD

*This is a free service for GPISD students in Texas. This is not insurance.

post_text:
Jadyn Sanzone is a senior at Young Women's Leadership Academy at Arnold. Jadyn moved schools frequently in elementary and didn’t find a stable school-home until coming to YWLA. She is actively involved in orchestra and is the concertmaster of YWLA’s Chamber Orchestra. Jadyn is also involved with TAFE and DECA. She plans to complete a bachelor’s degree at Southwestern University with a double major in Psychology and Music.

"YWLA was the first school I felt at home in. It allowed me to open up and be more confident in myself. I went from a shy, timid 8th grader who couldn’t speak up for herself to a confident, empowering senior who is about to embark on the next journey in their life. I plan to complete a bachelor’s degree, double majoring in Psychology and Music. I want to develop a new form of therapy that allows treatment to be personalized with a person’s brainwaves." #GPISDGraduates

#GPISDHometownHero
Erica Roberts was nominated to be a GPISDHometown Hero by her son,Noah, a student at School for the Highly Gifted- GPISD.

Noah wrote... “my Mom is one (HometownHero) because she works for UPS and loads trucks by hands, and she has to still go to work during this time, and she does because she knows she has to makes sure that package gets to the hospital because it is medical supplies or to people that can't get out of the house so they order food online or for anyone who just needs something to cure their boredom. I am just so proud to call her my Mom and I think it's pretty cool that she does what she does especially during this time. They call her an essential employee but she has always been essential to me. Thank you. (On a side note she doesn't know I nominated her; she tries to sleep as much as she can during the day since she works overnight)."

Thank you, Noah, and thank you to your mom, GPISD thanks you for your service. #WeAreGPISD #GPISDstillLeading

post_text:
At the recent Visual Arts Scholastic Event State Art Competition, GPISD had 26 entries from 25 students. At the State level, 22 students earned Gold Medals, 4 earned Silver Medals, and 2 earned the Gold Seal, the highest honor in the State VASE competition.

Congratulations to all these students and their teachers. To view the winning works visit https://www.gpisd.org/Domain/11812. #GPISDstillCreating #WeAreGPISD

Calling all campers! GPISD is hosting Camp Invention virtually this summer. Camp Invention is a high-energy, hands-on STEM camp. Camp Invention materials will be mailed to every student's home address, and our Camp Invention Director and Coaches will host virtual meeting times to engage our daring inventors!

For registration and scholarship information visit our website. https://www.gpisd.org/Page/47115
#GPISDstillLearning #WeAreGPISD

post_text: Congratulations to Dubiski Career High School Graphic Communications Junior, Tracy Vuu. Tracy created a cookbook cover design that was selected as the cover for the LOH foundation Family Cookbook. This was a junior class ad design project/contest that began in February and was completed before Spring Break. After her design was selected, Tracy continued to work with community supporter Lynn McGinley and the LOH Foundation despite our school building being closed via email. Great job Tracy. #GPISDstillLearning #WeAreGPISD

post_text:
Grand Prairie ISD is proud to announce that our Class of 2020 will have their Graduation Ceremonies at Globe Life Field, home of the Texas Rangers. The ceremonies will be held on June 4 and 5.

Thursday, June 4.
2:30pm South Grand Prairie High School
7:30pm Dubiski Career High School

Friday, June 5
1:30pm GPHSGophers
5:30pm Crosswinds Accelerated High School
8:30pm Young Women's Leadership Academy at Arnold, Grand Prairie Fine Arts Academy & Grand Prairie Collegiate Institute

Look for more details to come from your campus principal. Find updates at gpisd.org/graduation. #WeAreGPISD #GPISDGraduates

post_text:
What may seem like typical teen behavior maybe something more. Your teen may be feeling anxious, overwhelmed, stressed, or facing a number of pressures. There are plenty of resources out there for supporting their emotional and physical changes, including a virtual counseling program through DialCare.

Middle and high school students now have a safe, secure and private way of seeking help from licensed mental health professionals for free via phone or video chat during after school hours.

What may seem like typical teen behavior maybe something more? Your teen may be feeling anxious, overwhelmed, stressed, or facing a number of pressures. There are plenty of resources out there for supporting their emotional and physical changes, including a virtual counseling program through DialCare!
*This is a free service for GPISD students in Texas. This is not insurance.

post_text:
Emmanuella Alawode has attended GPISD schools since the second grade. She is an alumnus of Ellen Ochoa STEM Academy at Ben Milam Elementary, Grand Prairie Collegiate Institute, and will graduate from South Grand Prairie High School. Emmanuella has been active in numerous organizations including SkillsUSA Health Science, National Honor Society, Academic Decathlon, Mayor's Teen Council, & Mu Alpha Theta. She has gathered many awards including Superintendent Scholar and QuestBridge Scholar. Her career plans are to become an OB/GYN and specialize in maternal-fetal medicine.

"I want to encourage everyone to stare your giants in the face and tell them that 'I can, and I will. You can always achieve your dreams, and you will if you put forth the effort. I’m a testimony of that and God's grace.”
#GPISDGraduates2020
text:

She has gathered many awards including Superintendent Scholar and QuestBridge Scholar. Her career plans are to become an OB/GYN and specialize in maternal-fetal medicine.

post_text:
#GPISDHometownHero
Jay Robinson is the husband of Dickinson Elementary teacher, Debi Scott, and the parent of Garner Fine Arts Academy 5th grader, Brayden. Jay is a veteran of the United States Air Force and is currently working as a field operations supervisor for Joerns Healthcare. Joerns Healthcare has doubled their production capacity to help support customers and caregivers with critical care products necessary to meet COVID-19 patient needs. Jay is working on the frontlines to ensure that acute-care hospitals, nursing homes, and other medical care facilities are receiving timely deliveries of essential medical supplies and products required to provide quality care for patients. GPISD thanks you for your service. #WeAreGPISD #GPISDstillLeading

post_text:
Jakob Swallom has attended Grand Prairie Fine Arts Academy since the 6th grade, the first year the school opened. Jakob is in the art strand. He has maintained all A's since his sophomore year while working a part-time job. Jakob has attended and medalled at the VASE competitions and advanced to State VASE once. He will attend Texas Tech in the fall majoring in Engineering.

"Words can't describe the incredible journey I've been on for the past 7 years at GPFAA. I feel that my growth through this experience is drastic and invaluable and I'm grateful for all the opportunities provided to me."
#GPISDGraduates2020

post_text: Get your cameras ready! The Blue Angels will fly over parts of Grand Prairie tomorrow. Show us your footage!
shared_text:
Fort Worth Alliance Air Show
May 5 at 1:41 PM ·

In a show of national solidarity, the U.S. Navy Blue Angels will flyover Dallas/Fort Worth on Wednesday, May 6, starting at 11 a.m. This is part of multiple flyovers across the nation called America Strong — a collaborative salute to honor healthcare workers, first responders and other essential frontline workers as they combat COVID-19. Residents should observe the flyover from the safety of their home-quarantine and should refrain from traveling to see the flyover. Social distancing should be practiced at all times.

The U.S. Navy Blue Angels were in North Texas last October at the #Bell Fort Worth #AllianceAirShow. The renowned Air Force Thunderbirds will fly at the 30th Anniversary of the Bell Fort Worth Alliance Air Show Oct. 17-18, 2020, at Fort Worth Alliance Airport. #AmericaStrong #InThisTogether
text:

Residents should observe the flyover from the safety of their home-quarantine and should refrain from traveling to see the flyover. Social distancing should be practiced at all times.

post_text: For our senior artist.
shared_text:
Eddie Bernice Johnson
May 4 at 8:05 PM ·

Calling all high school students in District 30!

The 2020 Art Competition is going digital! All entries will need to be submitted online. We request photos/scans of your entry to be uploaded with this form found here: https://forms.gle/kAkMty6qeyVADwsP7

The top 3 winners (third place, runner up, and our first place winner) will be notified. The first place winner's piece will be displayed on my website and social media. It will also be sent to Washington, D.C. to hang in the Tunnels below the Capitol.

*The deadline for submissions is May 28, 2020.*

post_text:
It's ok to not be ok. Asking for help is a sign of strength. Now, in addition to GPISD counselors being available to students by email, phone, and ZOOM, GPISD is offering after-hours counseling services through DialCare. Students in grades 6-12 can reach out through the DialCare app or phone.

We know these are trying times. If you need to talk to someone, we have trained professionals ready. Take control of your well-being. Take care of yourself because self-care matters at every age. GPISD is here for you.

gpisd.org/DialCare

post_text:
Grand Prairie ISD Board Names Lone Finalist

The Grand Prairie ISD Board of Trustees named Linda Ellis as the lone finalist in its search for a new superintendent.
Ms. Ellis is currently serving as the District’s Interim Superintendent and has worked in public education for 26 years.

“Ms. Ellis has done a tremendous job leading our District through two significant events,” said School Board President Burke Hall. “Her leadership has been a steadying presence in the wake of the loss of Dr. Hull and again with the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on our schools. We feel she will further the vision of GPISD and lead us into the next chapter of Grand Prairie Schools.”

According to state law, the school board must wait 21 days before offering her a contract. If hired, she will be the second female superintendent in the district’s history.
text:
Grand Prairie ISD Board Names Lone Finalist

The Grand Prairie ISD Board of Trustees named Linda Ellis as the lone finalist in its search for a new superintendent.
Ms. Ellis is currently serving as the District’s Interim Superintendent and has worked in public education for 26 years.

“Ms. Ellis has done a tremendous job leading our District through two significant events,” said School Board President Burke Hall. “Her leadership has been a steadying presence in the wake of the loss of Dr. Hull and again with the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on our schools. We feel she will further the vision of GPISD and lead us into the next chapter of Grand Prairie Schools.”

According to state law, the school board must wait 21 days before offering her a contract. If hired, she will be the second female superintendent in the district’s history.

post_text:
Be Kind In Your Community
GPISD appreciates our community helpers, food service, delivery, grocery, and frontline workers who are continuing to work during this shutdown. We can help them by staying at home so our community helpers can focus on those most in need. When you must go out, wear a mask to protect others. Being kind in our community has a whole new meaning now. #BeKindGPISD #WeAreGPISD

post_text:
Earlier today, Governor Greg Abbott issued an Executive Order closing all Texas schools for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year.

As a result, GPISD will continue at-home learning through our last day of school in May. Information regarding the logistics of upcoming events, including graduation, will be forthcoming as we are provided additional guidance from state, county and city agencies.

More information about providing access to schools for students and staff members to obtain their belongings will be communicated once a safe process is determined.

If you have any questions, please send them to coronavirus@gpisd.org.

Please continue to adhere to the guidance provided by medical professionals to stay well. We look forward to the time we can all be together again in our schools and classrooms safely.

At-Home Learning Academy found at www.gpisd.org/AHA

post_text:
In this mobile age, technology has become increasingly valuable in supporting new generations of lifelong learners and readers. Grand Prairie ISD and Grand Prairie Libraries have formed an innovative new partnership using ebooks and e-audiobooks to increase access to more reading materials for students. This unique collaboration strives to promote literacy and digital learning by combining the schools’ and the library’s digital reading resources in one app. As a result, students learn anytime, anywhere because of the convenience, ease of reading on-the-go and the inherent popularity of technology.

Through Sora, the student reading app for GPISD, students can borrow from both the district and Grand Prairie Public Library System’s juvenile and young adult digital collection. For more information visit gpisd.org/AHA.
text:
In this mobile age, technology has become increasingly valuable in supporting new generations of lifelong learners and readers. Grand Prairie ISD and Grand Prairie Libraries have formed an innovative new partnership using ebooks and e-audiobooks to increase access to more reading materials for students. This unique collaboration strives to promote literacy and digital learning by combining the schools’ and the library’s digital reading resources in one app. As a result, students learn anytime, anywhere because of the convenience, ease of reading on-the-go and the inherent popularity of technology.

Through Sora, the student reading app for GPISD, students can borrow from both the district and Grand Prairie Public Library System’s juvenile and young adult digital collection. For more information visit gpisd.org/AHA.

post_text:
Dulce Espinoza is a kind and hard-working student at Young Women's Leadership Academy at Arnold. She has a passion for helping people and has been accepted into the Texas Woman’s University’s nursing program. Throughout high school, she has kept her academics high and push through her obstacles. She credits her loving family for helping their support. Dulce is involved in the National Honors Society, Skills USA, and Lacrosse. She has been awarded over $10,000 in scholarship money due to her high academic record and perseverance.

"YWLA.has provided us with amazing opportunities such as scholarships, placement in varsity sports, and outstanding leadership positions in different organizations- without these opportunities I wouldn't be the well-rounded young lady that I am today." - Dulce Espinoza '20 #GPISDGraduates #Graduation2020

post_text:
With the COVID-19 closure, Grand Prairie ISD was challenged to create opportunities to continue engaging our students in learning. That challenge has resulted in the creation of our At-Home Academy. The three-fold purpose of our At-Home Academy is to:

1) ensure students are able to continue learning and growing academically;
2) ensure students have the opportunity to maintain face-to-face learning with their same assigned teacher and classmates virtually; and
3) engage our students in a 21st-century learning environment to ensure they are equipped and prepared to meet the continued needs of our society.
Visit www.gpisd.org/AHA

post_text:
Jocelyn Carrasquillo is a Girl Scout, scholar, softball player and is currently Miss Grand Prairie Latina. This multi-talented young lady attended Florence Hill Elem., YWLA, and will graduate from SGP with the Class of 2020. With over 1000 service hours accumulated; Jocelyn will attend UTA in the fall majoring in Mechanical Engineering. She is a member of the National Honor Society and voted a class favorite.

“My years at South Grand Prairie has been a journey full of memories and opportunities! I’m thankful for playing a sport I love with the Softball Lady Warriors and building a sister bond. “ - Jocelyn Carrasquillo ‘20
#GPISDGraduates #Graduation2020

post_text: Common symptoms of #COVID19 are fever, dry cough, & shortness of breath. If you have mild symptoms, call your doctor & #StayHome. If you develop serious symptoms, such as trouble breathing, pressure in the chest, or bluish lips or face, call your doctor & seek care immediately. #WeAreGPISD

post_text: April is Be Kind in Your Community Month. During this time of Shelter-In-Place, being kind in your community has new meaning. Practice social distancing the help flatten the curve and to help our health care workers. When shopping, remember to practice one cart/one person. Get exercise, eat healthy and keep in touch with friends remotely. By following the guidelines during this time, we do our part to stop the spread of COVID 19 in our community. #BeKindGPISD #BeKindInYourCommunity #WeAreGPISD

Right now there are many stressors in our life, for our family. Your mental health is just as important and is linked to your physical health. Many of our schools practice mindfulness. This is a great activity to incorporate into your family's daily schedule. Remember that it is an exercise that you need to practice to improve. #GPISDBeKindToYourself #GPISDstillLeading #WeAreGPISD

post_text: In an effort to help GPISD families with limited Internet access, GPISD has extended its WiFi access points at each campus and district building. The WiFi zones are extended into the parking lot as far as they will allow. Students can join the network using their regular login credentials. We encourage everyone to engage in safe social distancing procedures when using these WiFi access points. For assistance please visit gpisd.org/TechHelp #WeAreGPISD #GPISDstillLearning

Practice Social Distancing

To avoid the spread of COVID-19 in our community, practice social distancing:
• Avoid going out in public
• When in public, keep six feet of distance between you and others
• Follow guidance provided by local and state officials.
Get more information at https://texas.gov/covid19
#covid19 #texasstrong #stayhome

post_text:
Based on an extension of the Executive Order by Texas Governor Abbott, Grand Prairie ISD campuses will remain closed to students and provide online instruction through at least Sunday, May 3, 2020.

We are here for our students, parents, and staff and will continue providing support academically, physically and socio-emotionally. Our teachers will continue to provide academic instruction, our counselors are offering social-emotional activities, and all staff are available by email to assist students and families during this time of need.

Please continue to watch our website and social media for updates. If you have specific questions, you may email them to coronavirus@gpisd.org or call 972-623-9000 Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to noon, and we will do our best to answer your questions. You may also visit www.gpisd.org/HealthUpdates to see our Frequently Asked Questions page.

https://gov.texas.gov/news/post/governor-abbott-issues-executive-order-implements-statewide-essential-services-and-activities-protocols?fbclid=IwAR0LSfSaoLzoE8sDyzgReU19qGviwNdttYwkI_GZruTU1fQOqpcUE5hKDX8

post_text:
Be Kind Online
With students being online more than ever, it is important to protect yourself in the digital world.
• Think about what you post. You never know what someone will forward or screenshot. Being kind to other will help keep you safe online.
• Do not share or repost anything that is hurtful or harmful to someone. Sharing or reposting embarrassing or hurtful items makes just as responsible for cyberbullying as the original poster. #BeKindGPISD #BeKindOnline #WeAreGPISD

post_text:
***Art Activity***
Puffy Sidewalk Chalk Paint Ingredients

1 cup flour
1 cup water
1 tablespoon dish soap – just about any dish soap will work.
5-10 drops food coloring or washable paint
How to Make Sidewalk Chalk Paint

* In a large mixing bowl stir together the flour and water until there are no lumps.

* Stir in the dish soap to the flour mixture.

* Add food coloring of your choice of color until the desired color is achieved.

* Pour the mixture into your squeeze bottle or use a ziplock bag and cut one corner off.

Use it all in one day, they explode if just left closed. Doesn't save well.

Post your Sidewalk Chalk Paint photos in the comments. #GPISDstillLearning

* credit to : https://www.midgetmomma.com/sidewalk-paint/

post_text: Thank you SkillsUSA Texas for finding a way to keep our students engaged.
shared_text:
SkillsUSA Texas
March 19 at 2:33 PM ·

The SkillsUSA Texas Virtual Championships is being created to meet the needs of these extraordinary circumstances and times currently being faced as a result of the coronavirus (COVID-19) and to comply with state government and agency limits of mass gatherings.

SkillsUSA Texas is committed to providing a quality experience to our membership. Advisors, technical committee members as well as business and industry partners have reached out to offer their assistance to ensure that our members have an opportunity to showcase their skills.

You can find an overview of the Virtual Championships on our SkillsUSA Texas website or follow this link: http://bit.ly/2UiHQvK

post_text:
UPDATED INFORMATION
Beginning Tuesday, March 17, Grand Prairie ISD will offer free, healthful meals to all children ages 0-18 years. There will be curbside pickup at every school with the exception of the combined schools listed below. Families may walk or drive, however, if you are driving no one will need to exit their personal vehicles. All participating children must be present whether walking or riding in a vehicle. Children do not have to be students at the campus to qualify for the meal, and families can visit any of the participating sites. Any child 0-18 is eligible for a meal.

7:00am-8:00am daily - Breakfast Curbside Pickup

10:30am-12:00pm daily - Lunch Curbside Pickup

Combined School Pickup Locations:
GPHS and GPFAA pick up at GPHS
Adams and Crosswinds pick up at Crosswinds
Alexander Building and SGPHS pick up at SGPHS
Dubiski, SHG and Marshall pick up at Marshall

If you have specific questions, please email your questions to coronavirus@gpisd.org or call 972-623-9000 Monday – Friday 8 am to noon and we will do our best to answer your questions.

Dr. Ellen Ochoa’s studies in physics and electrical engineering led her to a career with NASA. She became the first Hispanic female astronaut, and in 1993, she became the first Hispanic woman to travel into space when she served aboard the Space Shuttle Discovery. Ellen Ochoa STEM Academy at Ben Milam Elementary in Grand Prairie ISD is proud to be named for such a distinguished Woman in STEM.#SheroesofSTEM

#PioneerofProgress

#WomenInSTEM

post_text: Happy Leap Day. February 29 comes around only once every 4 years to sync our calendar to the Earth’s movement around the Sun. While the modern calendar contains 365 days, the actual time it takes for Earth to orbit its star is slightly longer—roughly 365.2421 days. Over time, those few hours add up. To ensure consistency with the true astronomical year, it is necessary to periodically add in an extra day to make up the lost time and get the calendar back in sync. Enjoy your extra day!
text: Happy Leap Day. February 29 comes around only once every 4 years to sync our calendar to the Earth’s movement around the Sun. While the modern calendar contains 365 days, the actual time it takes for Earth to orbit its star is slightly longer—roughly 365.2421 days. Over time, those few hours add up. To ensure consistency with the true astronomical year, it is necessary to periodically add in an extra day to make up the lost time and get the calendar back in sync. Enjoy your extra day!

post_text:
GPISD celebrates Black History Month with Voices of Inspiration.

Muhammad Ali was an Olympic and World Champion boxer. In 1999, Ali was crowned “Sportsman of the Century” by Sports Illustrated. He won numerous boxing championship as well as an Olympic gold medal. Ali was the recipient of the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2005. #BlackHistoryMonth

“Impossible is just a big word thrown around by small men who find it easier to live in the world they’ve been given than to explore the power they have to change it. Impossible is not a fact. It’s an opinion. Impossible is not a declaration. It’s a dare. Impossible is potential. Impossible is temporary. Impossible is nothing.”

“Impossible is just a big word thrown around by small men who find it easier to live in the world they’ve been given than to explore the power they have to change it. Impossible is not a fact. It’s an opinion. Impossible is not a declaration. It’s a dare. Impossible is potential. Impossible is temporary. Impossible is nothing.”

post_text:
Congratulations to the GPISD art students who competed in the Region Ten South Visual Arts Scholastic Event on Saturday, Feb. 22 .GPISD student artists entered 237 2D and 3D artworks with 212 earning a Regional Gold Medal.

Of the 212 Regional Gold Medals, 26 earned an Area Gold Medal, which means they are advancing to the State Competition in April.

Gold Medal Awards by High School:
GPHS 37
GPFAA 64
SGPHS 93
YWLA 7
Dubiski HS 11

The Region Ten South VASE competition was extremely competitive, with a total of 1949 entries.
The standards to earn a Gold Medal are higher every year.
GPISD artists showcased art that is so accomplished and high quality, with unique points of view and creative originality.
Giant congratulations also to the high school Teacher/Artist/Mentors who have been guiding the students in this process since last September.

post_text:
February is Teen Dating Violence Awareness Month. Be informed what to look for and how to talk to your teen about healthy relationships.
• Girls and young women between the ages of 16 and 24 experience the highest rate of intimate partner violence — almost triple the national average.
• Among female victims of intimate partner violence, 94% of those age 16-19 and 70% of those age 20-24 were victimized by a current or former boyfriend or girlfriend.
• Violent behavior typically begins between the ages of 12 and 18.
• The severity of intimate partner violence is often greater in cases where the pattern of abuse was established in adolescence.

post_text:
GPISD celebrates Black History Month with Voices of Inspiration.

Venus Williams is an American tennis player. She is credited with ushering in a new era of power on the women's professional tennis tour. She has won seven Grand Slam Singles titles and fourteen Grand Slam Doubles titles. Venus Williams has overcome injury and losses to be one of the top ranked players in the world. #BlackHistoryMonth

"You have to believe in yourself when no one else does—that makes you a winner right there." - Venus Williams

post_text:
GPISD celebrates Black History Month with Voices of Inspiration.

Booker T. Washington was an educator, author, and speaker. Born in 1856, he left home at the age of 16 and walked 500 miles to Hampton Normal Agricultural Institute in Virginia where he persuaded administrators to allow him to attend the school.
Always a believer in the power of education, he later founded Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute in Alabama (now known as Tuskegee University). Washington was an advisor to both Presidents Theodore Roosevelt and William Taft. #BlackHistoryMonth

"Success is to be measured not so much by the position that one has reached in life as by the obstacles which he has overcome while trying to succeed. " - Booker T. Washington

post_text:
GPISD will offer all Juniors to chance to take the SAT at school on March 4, 2020. In order to make the most of this opportunity, students can practice using Khan Academy. The practice is free and the sign up is easy. Twenty hours of practice on Khan Academy is associated with an average 115-point score increase from the PSAT/NMSQT to the SAT, nearly double the average gain without Khan.

In 2017, Khan Academy and the College Board, the maker of the SAT, analyzed gains between the PSAT/NMSQT and the SAT and found a positive relationship between use of Official SAT Practice and score improvements on the SAT. Score gains are consistent across gender, family income, race, ethnicity and parental education level.
text:
GPISD will offer all Juniors to chance to take the SAT at school on March 4, 2020. In order to make the most of this opportunity, students can practice using Khan Academy. The practice is free and the sign up is easy. Twenty hours of practice on Khan Academy is associated with an average 115-point score increase from the PSAT/NMSQT to the SAT, nearly double the average gain without Khan.

In 2017, Khan Academy and the College Board, the maker of the SAT, analyzed gains between the PSAT/NMSQT and the SAT and found a positive relationship between use of Official SAT Practice and score improvements on the SAT. Score gains are consistent across gender, family income, race, ethnicity and parental education level.

$2.7 Billion. That’s the amount of financial aid money that was unclaimed last year. GPISD wants to assist our students in earning all the financial aid for which they eligible. The seven GPISD high schools will be competing in the FAFSA Challenge during January. If you are a senior who has not completed the FAFSA, you can attend the FAFSA workshop on January 9 or visit with your counselor for help. GPISD works with our families because we know teamwork makes the dream work.

2 Ways to win the GPISD FAFSA Challenge (ending February 17)
* The campus with the highest percentage of FAFSA completion for the Class of 2020.
* The campus with the highest percentage of FAFSA increase compared to the Class of 2019 data.

Complete the FAFSA to claim your future!

Pamela Pardo, Dubiski Career High School Graphics Junior will represent GPISD competing against 17 other north Texas School Districts for the 2020 edition of the Medical City Children's Hospital Kids Teaching Kids recipe book. post_text: A short time ago, a mechanical failure in the HVAC system at Whitt Fine Arts Academy produced a small amount of smoke in the music room. As a precaution, the building was evacuated, and the Grand Prairie Fire Department was notified. The GPFD confirmed there was no fire and students are back in the building. There is no longer any smoke in the building, and all music classes have been rerouted to a different location for the rest of the day while our maintenance department continues to monitor the situation. All children and staff are safe.
text: A short time ago, a mechanical failure in the HVAC system at Whitt Fine Arts Academy produced a small amount of smoke in the music room. As a precaution, the building was evacuated, and the Grand Prairie Fire Department was notified. The GPFD confirmed there was no fire and students are back in the building. There is no longer any smoke in the building, and all music classes have been rerouted to a different location for the rest of the day while our maintenance department continues to monitor the situation. All children and staff are safe.

post_text: Grand Prairie ISD’s American Indian Education Program recently hosted an engaging workshop about the rich history, diverse cultures, and important contributions of our nation’s First People. In addition to speakers and storytellers, participants also created art. The current November art show at the GPISD Education Center honors Native American Heritage Month.
